name.text: Getting an assets value over time.

questiontext.text:
\(\text{@rams@}\) bought an item costing Ksh. \({@P@}\). Its value goes up by \({@r@}\)% every year. How much will it be worth after \({@n@}\)years?

Ksh. [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

generalfeedback.text:
worked solution

Appreciation means the value is increasing.

A \({@r@}\)% increase means the itemâ€™s value becomes \({@R@}\)% of what it was the year before.

\({@R@}\)% as a decimal is:

= \(\frac{109}{100}\) = \({@rate@}\)

So, each year, the value is multiplied by \({@rate@}\)

Multiply the value times \({@n@}\) (for \({@n@}\) years)

We multiply first by the cost of the current year \({@P@}\) before it appreciates , and multiply it by \({@rate@}^{{@n@}}\) times:

Value after 6 years = \({@P@} \times {@rate@}^{{@n@}} \)

Using a calculator:

First, calculate \({@rate@}^{{@n@}}\)

Then multiply by \({@P@}\)

\({@P@} \times {@rate@}^{{@n@}}\)

= \({@float(A)@}\)

= \({@float@}\) to 2dp
